column1: Hi all,After recommendations for afternoon tea post lockdown for myself, the hubby and our daughter who will be twenty one. We will be spending the day, (which will be a Monday) in London shopping in and around Oxford Street and Borough Market. Then afternoon tea, We're happy to splash out as it is for a special birthday, the venue I'm open to ideas, for us the food must be amazing with a nice ambiance, later on we intend to go to the Shard for a drink at Sunset and then make our way home, Many thanks for any information given.
I hope your Daughter is only 19 just now!I can’t see any of your plans being fulfilled in the next 6 months!
madscotsman not sure I said it was in the next six months..........

The best afternoon tea I've had is at the Savoy. Very formal atmosphere in some ways, but I found the service very friendly and the entire setting and presentation to be elegant. (And I don't remember being disappointed by the food.) Second-best is the Renaissance St. Pancras, more for the atmosphere and service, although the food is very good.Future results, of course, may vary.
Had afternoon tea at Fortnum & Mason a few months ago . Very smart room and would happily return for more food.

Madscotsman that made me laugh out loud. Tough thing to do these days :-)Sorry Yvonne, no disrespect but it was a snappy reposte :-)

The OP doesn't indicate when the trip to London is scheduled/planned. Your daughter's birthday may likely have to be celebrated at home before a trip to London is possible.And sorry, with all due respect, what 21 year old daughter wouldn't want to hop on a train with friends and stay in London overnight to celebrate, enjoying music, food, drinks, etc. in London pubs??

I too would choose the Savoy for both the food and the ambience. An alternative to the Shard may be a drink at the Sky Garden if that's of interest to your daughter.This thread may attract one of the forum's usual suspects, who will comment about the ownership of the Savoy or any other venue, the income of those who frequent such places, may provide a website that will have nothing to do with the matter at hand, and will denigrate some choices and praise others as a cack-handed attempt to demonstrate superiority. You'll know the post when you see it.
My favourite is Browns on Albemarle Street - it is convenient for Oxford Street (close to the bottomend of Bond Street) and is a proper traditional AT.

Yvonne - me too - just dreaming of the time I can hug my grandchildren again after eight weeks and see my son in London. By the way, about four years ago, my mum, daughter and I had a fab afternoon tea at the Landmark Hotel on Marylebone Rd. The sandwiches (which they kept bringing til we were bursting), bottomless cups of tea and little patisseries were delicious and there was a pianist playing too. It was served in the huge centre courtyard (glazed, so indoors) and the staff were lovely - a real treat.

Hello Yvonne - such a good idea to give your family something to look forward to, when circumstances change, whenever that may be. Though not a formal afternoon tea, I could recommend the biscuiteers for tea and a selection of the most amazing iced biscuits. There is also a lovely bakery in Bloomsbury - can't remember the name but it's pale pink and on Instagram posts so you'll soon find it. Fine dining afternoon teas do seem to be overrated (and overpriced) in my opinion so I couldn't really recommend any of them.
